column2: Herr Stein sees and hears that I am more of a player than Beecke,--that without making grimaces of any kind I play so expressively that, according to his own confession, no one shows off his pianoforte as well as I. column2: Whoever can see and hear her (the daughter of Stein) play without laughing must be a stone (Stein) like her father.	Whoever can see and hear her (the daughter of Stein) play without laughing must be a stone (Stein) like her father.

column2: She sits opposite the treble instead of in the middle of the instrument, so that there may be greater opportunities for swaying about and making grimaces.
column3: She sits opposite the treble instead of in the middle of the instrument, so that there may be greater opportunities for swaying about and making grimaces.

column2: Then she rolls up her eyes and smirks.
column3: Then she rolls up her eyes and smirks.

column2: If a passage occurs twice it is played slower the second time; if three times, still slower.
column3: If a passage occurs twice it is played slower the second time; if three times, still slower.

column2: When a passage comes up goes the arm, and if there is to be an emphasis it must come from the arm, heavily and clumsily, not from the fingers.
column3: When a passage comes up goes the arm, and if there is to be an emphasis it must come from the arm, heavily and clumsily, not from the fingers.

column2: But the best of all is that when there comes a passage (which ought to flow like oil) in which there necessarily occurs a change of fingers, there is no need of taking care; when the time comes you stop, lift the hand and nonchalantly begin again.
column3: But the best of all is that when there comes a passage (which ought to flow like oil) in which there necessarily occurs a change of fingers, there is no need of taking care; when the time comes you stop, lift the hand and nonchalantly begin again.

column2: When I told Herr Stein that I would like to play on his organ and that I was passionately fond of the instrument, he marveled greatly and said: 'What, a man like you, so great a clavier player, want to play on an instrument which has no douceur, no expression, neither piano nor forte, but goes on always the same?' 'But all that signifies nothing; to me the organ is nevertheless the king of instruments.'
column3: When I told Herr Stein that I would like to play on his organ and that I was passionately fond of the instrument, he marveled greatly and said: 'What, a man like you, so great a clavier player, want to play on an instrument which has no douceur, no expression, neither piano nor forte, but goes on always the same?' 'But all that signifies nothing; to me the organ is nevertheless the king of instruments.'

column2: (Augsburg, October 17, 1777, to his father.)
column3: (Augsburg, october seventeenth seventeen seventy seven, to his father.)

column2: I had the pleasure to hear Herr Franzl (whose wife is a sister of Madame Cannabich) play a concerto on the violin.	I had the pleasure to hear Herr Franzl (whose wife is a sister of Madame Cannabich) play a concerto on the violin.

column2: He pleases me greatly.
column3: He pleases me greatly.

column2: You know that I am no great lover of difficulties.
column3: You know that I am no great lover of difficulties.

column2: He plays difficult things, but one does not recognize that they are difficult, but imagines that one could do the same thing at once; that is true art.
column3: He plays difficult things, but one does not recognize that they are difficult, but imagines that one could do the same thing at once; that is true art.

column2: He also has a beautiful, round tone,--not a note is missing, one hears everything; everything is well marked.
column3: He also has a beautiful, round tone,--not a note is missing, one hears everything; everything is well marked.

column2: He has a fine staccato bow, up as well as down; and I have never heard so good a double shake as his.
column3: He has a fine staccato bow, up as well as down; and I have never heard so good a double shake as his.

column2: In a word, though he is no wizard he is a solid violinist."
column3: In a word, though he is no wizard he is a solid violinist."

column2: In this: To play in the proper tempo; give expression to every note, appoggiatura, etc., tastefully and as they are written, so as to create the impression that the player had composed the piece."

column2: Herr Richter plays much and well so far as execution is concerned, but--as you will hear--crudely, laboriously and without taste or feeling; he is one of the best fellows in the world, and without a particle of vanity.	Herr Richter plays much and well so far as execution is concerned, but-as you will hear-crudely, laboriously and without taste or feeling; he is one of the best fellows in the world, and without a particle of vanity.
column3: true

column2: Whenever I played for him he looked immovably at my fingers, and one day he said 'My God! how I am obliged to torment myself and sweat, and yet without obtaining applause; and for you, my friend, it is mere play!' 'Yes,' said I, 'I had to labor once in order not to show labor now.' "
column3: Whenever I played for him he looked immovably at my fingers, and one day he said 'My God! how I am obliged to torment myself and sweat, and yet without obtaining applause; and for you, my friend, it is mere play!' 'Yes,' said I, 'I had to labor once in order not to show labor now.' "

column2: Meissner, as you know, has the bad habit of purposely making his voice tremble, marking thus entire quarter and eighth notes; I never could endure it in him.	Meissner, as you know, has the bad habit of purposely making his voice tremble, marking thus entire quarter and eighth notes; I never could endure it in him.
column3: true

column2: It is indeed despicable and contrary to all naturalness in song.
column3: It is indeed despicable and contrary to all naturalness in song.

column2: True the human voice trembles of itself, but only in a degree that remains beautiful; it is in the nature of the voice.
column3: True the human voice trembles of itself, but only in a degree that remains beautiful; it is in the nature of the voice.

column2: We imitate it not only on wind instruments but also on the viols and even on the clavier.
column3: We imitate it not only on wind instruments but also on the viols and even on the clavier.

column2: But as soon as you overstep the limit it is no longer beautiful because it is contrary to nature."
column3: But as soon as you overstep the limit it is no longer beautiful because it is contrary to nature."

column2: [The statement that the tremolo effect could be imitated on the clavier seems to require an explanation.

column2: Mozart obviously had in view, not the pianoforte which was just coming into use in his day, but the clavichord. This instrument was sounded by striking the strings with bits of brass placed in the farther end of the keys which were simple and direct levers.
column3: Mozart obviously had in view, not the pianoforte which was just coming into use in his day, but the clavichord. This instrument was sounded by striking the strings with bits of brass placed in the farther end of the keys which were simple and direct levers.

column2: The tangents, as they were called, had to be held against the strings as long as it was desired that the tone should sound, and by gently repeating the pressure on the key a tremulousness was imparted to the tone which made the clavichord a more expressive instrument than the harpsichord or the early pianoforte.
column3: The tangents, as they were called, had to be held against the strings as long as it was desired that the tone should sound, and by gently repeating the pressure on the key a tremulousness was imparted to the tone which made the clavichord a more expressive instrument than the harpsichord or the early pianoforte.

column2: The effect was called Bebung in German, and Balancement in French.
column3: The effect was called Bebung in German, and Balancement in French.

column2: You can imagine that it was all the more unendurable because I did not dare to say to him: 'Much too quick!' Moreover it is much easier to play rapidly than slowly; you can drop a few notes in passages without any one noticing it.

column2: At such speed you can use the hands indiscriminately; but is that beautiful?"
